variant.question: Which of these statements about trimming in an irreversible flight control system of a conventional aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
firstCorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control column does not change when using the pitch trim.
firstIncorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control column changes when using the pitch trim.
secondCorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control wheel changes when using the aileron trim.
secondIncorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim.

variant.question: An aircraft is powered down, and the rudder is at full left deflection, but the rudder pedals are centred. What can we say about the aircraft's control system?

options.text: Reversible controls.
Irreversible controls.
Power assisted controls.
Any type of control system could be used since the rudder position and pedal position are independent of each other after shutdown.

variant.question: In a reversible Flight Control System, movement of a control surface will result in..

options.text: a corresponding movement of the pilot\`s control.
activation of the anti-jamming function.
the pilot\`s control remaining in its current position.
isolation of both pilots\` controls.

variant.question: Given an aeroplane with irreversible primary flight controls, how is control maintained if one hydraulic system is lost due to a hydraulic leak?

options.text: By switching the flight control system to the reversible mode.
Sufficient reserve hydraulic fluid is available to compensate the effects of the leak.
By switching to manual back-up mode.
The remaining systems will take over control.

variant.question: An irreversible flight control system is one that is..

options.text: partially powered.
completely mechanical.
not powered.
fully powered.

variant.question: A flight control surface actuator is said to be "irreversible" when:

options.text: there is a need to lock the flight controls on the ground.
the pilot does not feel any force when moving that control surface in flight.
there is no feedback to the pilot\`s controls of the aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.
the flight control system has an alternate means of control in case of a control jam.

variant.question: Which of these statements is correct as regards trimming in an irreversible flight control system of a conventional aeroplane equipped with a trimmable horizontal stabiliser?
firstCorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control column does not change when using the pitch trim.
firstIncorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control column changes when using the pitch trim.
secondCorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control wheel changes when using the aileron trim.
secondIncorrectStatements: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim.

variant.question: Rudder trim adjustment in an aeroplane with irreversible flight controls is:

options.text: an adjustment of the zero force rudder position.
unnecessary because this aeroplane does not need rudder trim.
an adjustment of the rudder ratio changer.
an adjustment of the rudder trim tab.

variant.question: The rudder is trimmed in a fully powered flight control system by..

options.text: moving the pilot\`s control column into a neutral position.
altering the neutral position of the artificial feel unit.
adjusting the position of the rudder trim tab.
moving the rudder limiter unit.

variant.question: Trimming of aileron and rudder in an irreversible flight control system ..

options.text: is not necessary.
is achieved by adjusting the “zero force point” of the feel system.
is not possible.
is achieved by adjusting the neutral point of the flight control actuator.

variant.question: A flight control surface actuator is said to be "reversible" when …

options.text: there is feedback to the pilot\`s controls of the aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.
the flight control system has an alternate means of control in case of a control jam.
the pilot does not feel any force when moving that flight control surface in flight.
there is a need to have an artificial feel system.
